title: Family Office and Estate Staff: Liquidating a Cellar Discreetly
metaTitle: Family Office Guide: Liquidating a Cellar Discreetly | Proof Cellars
metaDescription: A guide for family office and estate staff liquidating wine and spirits cellars. Covers discretion, scheduling, inventory formats, and documentation requirements.
summary: Family offices and estate staff often manage cellar liquidations for principals who value privacy. This guide covers how to handle these transactions with appropriate discretion.

sections.heading: What to Do Next
content: Confirm authorization from the appropriate decision-maker. For family offices, this may require approval from the principal, a family member, or a designated officer.
Determine what inventory documentation exists. Professional cellars often have detailed records. Export these if available.
list: Confirm authorization from the principal or decision-maker
Export inventory from cellar management systems
Note any scheduling constraints or privacy requirements
Identify who will be the point of contact
Submit inventory and photos for an offer

sections.heading: What Information Matters for Pricing
content: Professional cellar inventories typically include the detail we need. If not, we can work with what you have.
list: Complete inventory with producer, vintage, quantity, size
Storage location and conditions
Original packaging status
Any bottles requiring special handling
Preferred documentation formats for records

sections.heading: Common Mistakes to Avoid
content: Discretion matters but should not prevent thorough documentation. Proper records protect all parties.
list: Proceeding without clear authorization
Insufficient documentation for financial records
Rushing without allowing time for proper valuation
Not specifying privacy requirements upfront
Coordinating logistics without appropriate staff involvement

sections.heading: How the Process Works
content: We adapt to your requirements and work within the constraints you specify.
list: Submit inventory through email, our form, or text to 213-770-9463
We provide a written offer in your preferred format
Review with decision-makers
If accepted, schedule logistics around your constraints
Payment is issued to the designated recipient with appropriate documentation

sections.heading: Privacy and Safety Notes
content: We work with high profile families and understand confidentiality requirements. Principal names are never disclosed.
We can sign confidentiality agreements if required before beginning the process.
All pickup and logistics can be coordinated to minimize visibility and align with household schedules.
Documentation is provided in formats suitable for your accounting and record-keeping requirements.

faqs.question: Can you sign an NDA before we share details?
faqs.answer: Yes. If confidentiality agreements are required, we can execute those before receiving inventory information.

faqs.question: How do you ensure discretion?
faqs.answer: We do not disclose principal names or transaction details. Pickups are scheduled to minimize visibility. All communications are confidential.

faqs.question: What documentation do you provide?
faqs.answer: We provide detailed offers and receipts. Formats can be adapted for your accounting systems or record-keeping requirements.

faqs.question: Can you work with professional storage facilities?
faqs.answer: Yes. We coordinate directly with storage facilities for inventory verification and transfer where permitted.

faqs.question: How long does the process take?
faqs.answer: Initial offers typically take one to five business days depending on collection size. Full transactions take two to six weeks depending on logistics.

faqs.question: Can we do this in phases?
faqs.answer: Yes. We can liquidate in batches if that works better for your situation.

faqs.question: Who should be the point of contact?
faqs.answer: You designate the contact. We communicate with whoever you specify and do not contact others without permission.
